documents.document: @DocMoschos @alanmcn1 @jack_fergie @StevenJDunn I am sorry - this wasn't "the data" - and this isn't about "nitpicking" the data. This was an extrapolation (not "the data") from so few data points that simply adding = to <= caused sensitivity to drop from 100% to 9%. I dont see how this isn't a massive red flag of an issue

@alanmcn1 @jack_fergie @StevenJDunn Like I said, the rest of the paper is terrific. It is measured and balanced and very well done. The rest of the paper I'd hold up as an example paper on how to evaluate these tests.

@alanmcn1 @jack_fergie @StevenJDunn Yes. Absolutely. But why put the 3% number when it's obviously based on such an extremely small sample size. The small N meant that a change of a symbol from "<" to "<=" caused a change in sensitivity from 100% to 9%. Is this not a major red flag on the statistics there?

@alanmcn1 @jack_fergie @StevenJDunn That said, the rest of the paper efforts into it are very well done. It's just the 3% piece that will catch any readers eye and immediately confuse the issue, particularly since it flies in the face of the rest of the paper - the rest was very well measured informative. 4/4

@alanmcn1 @jack_fergie @StevenJDunn I wouldn't harp so much on this here except that this was pointed out many times pre-publication and yet this flawed statistic which made international headlines wasn't fixed. This is the type of inappropriate use of stats that leads to a lot of public confusion. 3/3

@alanmcn1 @jack_fergie @StevenJDunn One need only look at sensitivity at Ct <29 (100%) vs. Ct <=29 (9%) to see the sample size was statistically FAR too small to make the upward extrapolation to claim a 3% sensitivity. If the addition of an equals sign in <= moves the needle from 100% to 9% that's a problem 2/x

@alanmcn1 @jack_fergie @StevenJDunn It is more measured, yes. And clearly lots of dedicated work. But the extrapolation from 6 high Ct positives to then put out a (misidentified) sensitivity metric of 3% is, in my opinion, unfortunately irresponsible, scientifically reckless, and confuses the public. 1/x
